This weekly bulletin informs students, parents, and staff about internships, academic
programs, jobs, leadership & community service initiatives, and other student
opportunities in a variety of fields. Please carefully note deadlines, age requirements,
and other pre-requisites for participation.
For ease of use, these newsletters are organized by different categories, such as
Academic Programs, Business Internships & Jobs, STEM Opportunities, Community
Service, and so on.
Please note that in order to save space, many sections contain links to general lists
of related opportunities- such as for Stem programs, Community Service, College
Prep free programs, and more - be sure to click on any links that interest you.
Students still seeking summer opportunities should select and apply ASAP to any of
the many opportunities in the various categories listed below (some free or low-cost) –
community service options, for example, can be part-time or full-time,
tutoring/helping younger students, working in parks, volunteering with local
government officials, and more. At this point students can’t be too picky, and should
consider any options that they might find interesting or enjoyable. Feel free to contact
Harvey Blumm at hblumm@stuy.edu for assistance & suggestions.
And a good number of programs for the fall term are now posting applications, such
as free CUNY College Now classes from various CUNY colleges (Academics
category), the Student Historian Internship Program (Government/Leadership
section), the virtual NY Academy of Science’s Junior Academy STEM Mentorship
program (STEM section), the volunteer Brooklyn Techies option from the Brooklyn
Public Library (Community Service category), and more. Some deadlines are due
soon, so check them out!
Some interesting programs to consider are highlighted below:
ACADEMICS: There are a variety of free or low-cost academic classes available over
the summer, ranging from Calculus to History to other STEM-related subjects – check
this section to learn more.
GOVERNMENT/LEADERSHIP/HISTORY: Students may now apply to several
excellent programs for the upcoming 2025-2026 school year. The NSLI Virtual
Language program starts in September and runs for two months – all students are
eligible to apply to learn Arabic, Chinese, Korean, Turkish & other languages– no
previous knowledge is required. The Legal Empowerment Fellows program at
Fordham Law School is open to current 9th, 10th, and 11th grade students.
And the Student Historian Internship Program at the New York Historical Society
in Manhattan welcomes applications from current 9th, 10th, and 11th graders with an
interest in history, research, and museum work. It runs on Wednesday afternoons, and
includes a $700 stipend for those who complete the program.
And, for the weeks ahead, all students may volunteer to help candidates for different
NYC government offices – two new options (for the Manhattan District Attorney
and Borough President races) are now listed in this section.
STEM: Current seniors may apply to the free Vaughn College Summer Engineering
Experience program – the application deadline for this four-week program is June
11th!
Current 9th, 10th, and 11th graders may apply for the free Urban Arts Digital
Academy program; there are virtual or Manhattan-based options.
And the New York Academy of Science offers their virtual Junior Academy for
students ages 13-17 during the 2025-2026 school year (check the exact age
requirements). Participants work with researchers and other students from around the
world on scientific solutions to “real-world problems.”
THEATER/ARTS: For current freshmen, sophomores, and juniors, the NYC Center
Preludes Musical Theater Program is a free one-week August opportunity to delve
into theater with experienced professionals – auditions take place next week, so apply
asap!
Questions, suggestions, and information about other opportunities are always
welcome and appreciated, and may be sent to Internship/Opportunity Coordinator
Harvey Blumm at: hblumm@stuy.edu - we will share your helpful information with
the Stuy community!

The New York City Department of Housing Develoment & Preservation Summer
Communications Internship
“This summer, we’re looking for motivated, curious students to join our small but
mighty Communications team at HPD — the city agency responsible for affordable
housing. Our interns get to do meaningful work that supports real-world housing
policy and programs, while also building a strong foundation in public service
communications.
The internship is designed as a well-rounded experience that touches on all
aspects of what we do — social media, press and storytelling, public engagement,
and event planning for senior leadership. Interns gain hands-on experience drafting
content, helping shape communications strategies, supporting public events, and
contributing to the narrative around how the City is tackling its housing challenges.
Interns will walk away with:
 tangible portfolio work and writing samples
 access to professional development resources
 networking opportunities with senior staff across the agency and city
government
 a deeper understanding of how large public institutions work — and how to
navigate them
We’re especially excited to hear from students who are passionate about public
service, housing equity, or storytelling that makes a difference. Urban studies,
journalism, communications, policy — all great backgrounds, but we’re open to
anyone with strong writing skills, attention to detail, and a willingness to jump in.”
